🚀 We Are Hiring: Senior QA Engineer (Manual) 🚀We are looking for an experienced QA Engineer! If you have 5+ years of IT experience and expertise in Manual testing across enterprise environments, we’d love to hear from you.🔹 Job Title: Senior QA Engineer  🔹 Experience: 5+ Years 🔹 Location: Bangalore 🔹 Job Type: Full-timeWhat You’ll Do:We are looking for a detail-oriented and experienced Manual QA Engineer to join our team. The ideal candidate will have a strong understanding of the Software Development Life Cycle (SDLC), Software Testing Life Cycle  (STLC) and database concepts. As a Manual QA Engineer, you will be responsible for performing manual testing, identifying bugs, and ensuring the overall quality of our software products.Key Responsibilities: Perform manual testing of web and mobile applications to ensure they meet the required standards of quality. Create, update, and execute test cases based on business requirements and specifications. Analyze business requirements, user stories, and technical specifications todevelop effective test plans. Execute functional, regression, integration, and system tests to identify defects and inconsistencies. Collaborate with development teams to understand product features, userstories, and technical specifications. Log and track defects using defect tracking tools and provide detailed reports on the findings. Participate in daily stand-ups, sprint planning, and review meetings to ensure alignment with project goals. Provide feedback on usability and user experience to improve the overall quality of the product. Work with the team to ensure that all critical issues are resolved before product releases. Validate database functionality by performing SQL queries to ensure dataaccuracy, integrity, and consistency. Collaborate with cross-functional teams, including developers, business analysts, and product managers, to ensure quality standards are met. Maintain and update test documentation and reports.Required Skills & Qualifications: Experience: 5+ years of experience in manual QA testing. Testing Knowledge: Solid understanding of the Software Development LifeCycle (SDLC) and Software Testing Life Cycle (STLC). Database Knowledge: Proficient in writing and executing SQL queries fordatabase validation. Tools: Experience with defect tracking tools (e.g., Jira) and test casemanagement tools (e.g., TestRail). Test Types: Experience in functional, regression, integration, and system testing.🎓 Education: Bachelor’s or master’s in computer science, IT, or a related field.📩 Interested? Send your resume to:aditi.joshi@meritech.co.in👉 If you or someone you know is a great fit, let’s connect! Drop a comment or send me a DM. 📩hashtag#Hiringhashtag#ManualQAhashtag#ManualTesterhashtag#ITJobs hashtag#Bangalore

We are hiring a skilled and proactive "Network & Cybersecurity Administrator" to manage and secure our plant’s digital infrastructure. This role is responsible for ensuring network security, safeguarding sensitive data, and maintaining compliance with industry cybersecurity standards. The ideal candidate will play a key role in preventing and responding to cyber threats across the organization’s operational and enterprise systems.Key Responsibilities:Network Security Management: Design, implement, and maintain secure network architectures, including firewalls, VPNs, and intrusion detection/prevention systems; Monitor network traffic for suspicious activity and respond to security incidents promptly.System Administration: Configure and manage network devices such as routers, switches, and servers; Perform regular updates and patches to ensure systems are protected against vulnerabilities.Cybersecurity Compliance: Ensure compliance with industry standards and regulations (e.g., ISO 27001, GDPR); Conduct regular security audits and vulnerability assessments.Incident Response: Develop and execute incident response plans to address security breaches Document and report security incidents and mitigation strategies.Collaboration and Training: Work closely with IT teams to implement best practices for securing network devices; Provide training to employees on cybersecurity awareness and protocols.Experience: 5–8 Years relevant experience.Qualifications:Bachelor’s degree in Cybersecurity, Information Technology, Computer Science, or related field (or equivalent experience); 3+ years of experience in a cybersecurity or network administration role; Strong knowledge of TCP/IP, firewalls, VPNs, IDS/IPS, and endpoint security; Experience with SIEM platforms (e.g., Splunk, IBM QRadar, or similar); Certifications such as CompTIA Security+, CEH, CISSP, or Cisco CCNA/CCNP Security preferred; Familiarity with industrial control systems (ICS), SCADA, or IIoT cybersecurity is a plus.Location: Gharo - SindhPlease share your cv at careers@armstrong-ze.com (mention position in subject line)hashtag#Hiring hashtag#Network hashtag#Cybersecurity hashtag#Engineer hashtag#Manufacturing

✍️The structure of high-performing data teams is evolving — and context is everything.🧠As a CDO in the banking sector, I see firsthand how the right data team composition depends heavily on company size, regulatory environment, and data maturity.The recent benchmark shared on the balance between Insights (46%), Data Engineering (43%), and Machine Learning (11%) resonates — but I’d add a few reflections based on experience leading data transformations in both traditional and digital banking environments:1. In early maturity stages, especially in highly regulated industries like banking, data engineering and governance are foundational. Without robust pipelines, metadata management, lineage tracking, and data quality controls, insights are unreliable — and regulatory risk increases.I often tell teams: “We earn the right to do ML by getting the basics right first.”2. As maturity builds, we focus on embedding analytics across the business — especially in risk, fraud, customer experience, and credit. This is where a strong layer of product analysts and embedded BI starts driving tangible business impact.3. At scale, roles like data product managers, governance leads, and ML engineers become critical — not just to deliver models, but to ensure they’re explainable, monitored, and integrated into decision systems.And increasingly, we’re seeing the need for platform thinking: building reusable data products, not just bespoke dashboards.AI-native tools are already reshaping what’s possible, but I believe the core value still lies in clarity, trust, and alignment between data and business goals.💡No one structure fits all — but understanding your current stage helps you build the right team, at the right time, to deliver real impact.🫵And hey — if you made it to the end: I’m currently hiring. We’re building something exciting, and I’m looking for data stewards, data engineers, and data scientists to join our team.DM me if you’re curious.hashtag#CDO hashtag#BankingInnovation hashtag#DataGovernance hashtag#AnalyticsEngineering hashtag#DataStrategy hashtag#DataLeadership hashtag#AIinBanking

✍️The structure of high-performing data teams is evolving — and context is everything.🧠As a CDO in the banking sector, I see firsthand how the right data team composition depends heavily on company size, regulatory environment, and data maturity.The recent benchmark shared on the balance between Insights (46%), Data Engineering (43%), and Machine Learning (11%) resonates — but I’d add a few reflections based on experience leading data transformations in both traditional and digital banking environments:1. In early maturity stages, especially in highly regulated industries like banking, data engineering and governance are foundational. Without robust pipelines, metadata management, lineage tracking, and data quality controls, insights are unreliable — and regulatory risk increases.I often tell teams: “We earn the right to do ML by getting the basics right first.”2. As maturity builds, we focus on embedding analytics across the business — especially in risk, fraud, customer experience, and credit. This is where a strong layer of product analysts and embedded BI starts driving tangible business impact.3. At scale, roles like data product managers, governance leads, and ML engineers become critical — not just to deliver models, but to ensure they’re explainable, monitored, and integrated into decision systems.And increasingly, we’re seeing the need for platform thinking: building reusable data products, not just bespoke dashboards.AI-native tools are already reshaping what’s possible, but I believe the core value still lies in clarity, trust, and alignment between data and business goals.💡No one structure fits all — but understanding your current stage helps you build the right team, at the right time, to deliver real impact.🫵And hey — if you made it to the end: I’m currently hiring. We’re building something exciting, and I’m looking for data stewards, data engineers, and data scientists to join our team.DM me if you’re curious.hashtag#CDO hashtag#BankingInnovation hashtag#DataGovernance hashtag#AnalyticsEngineering hashtag#DataStrategy hashtag#DataLeadership hashtag#AIinBanking

✍️The structure of high-performing data teams is evolving — and context is everything.🧠As a CDO in the banking sector, I see firsthand how the right data team composition depends heavily on company size, regulatory environment, and data maturity.The recent benchmark shared on the balance between Insights (46%), Data Engineering (43%), and Machine Learning (11%) resonates — but I’d add a few reflections based on experience leading data transformations in both traditional and digital banking environments:1. In early maturity stages, especially in highly regulated industries like banking, data engineering and governance are foundational. Without robust pipelines, metadata management, lineage tracking, and data quality controls, insights are unreliable — and regulatory risk increases.I often tell teams: “We earn the right to do ML by getting the basics right first.”2. As maturity builds, we focus on embedding analytics across the business — especially in risk, fraud, customer experience, and credit. This is where a strong layer of product analysts and embedded BI starts driving tangible business impact.3. At scale, roles like data product managers, governance leads, and ML engineers become critical — not just to deliver models, but to ensure they’re explainable, monitored, and integrated into decision systems.And increasingly, we’re seeing the need for platform thinking: building reusable data products, not just bespoke dashboards.AI-native tools are already reshaping what’s possible, but I believe the core value still lies in clarity, trust, and alignment between data and business goals.💡No one structure fits all — but understanding your current stage helps you build the right team, at the right time, to deliver real impact.🫵And hey — if you made it to the end: I’m currently hiring. We’re building something exciting, and I’m looking for data stewards, data engineers, and data scientists to join our team.DM me if you’re curious.hashtag#CDO hashtag#BankingInnovation hashtag#DataGovernance hashtag#AnalyticsEngineering hashtag#DataStrategy hashtag#DataLeadership hashtag#AIinBanking

✍️The structure of high-performing data teams is evolving — and context is everything.🧠As a CDO in the banking sector, I see firsthand how the right data team composition depends heavily on company size, regulatory environment, and data maturity.The recent benchmark shared on the balance between Insights (46%), Data Engineering (43%), and Machine Learning (11%) resonates — but I’d add a few reflections based on experience leading data transformations in both traditional and digital banking environments:1. In early maturity stages, especially in highly regulated industries like banking, data engineering and governance are foundational. Without robust pipelines, metadata management, lineage tracking, and data quality controls, insights are unreliable — and regulatory risk increases.I often tell teams: “We earn the right to do ML by getting the basics right first.”2. As maturity builds, we focus on embedding analytics across the business — especially in risk, fraud, customer experience, and credit. This is where a strong layer of product analysts and embedded BI starts driving tangible business impact.3. At scale, roles like data product managers, governance leads, and ML engineers become critical — not just to deliver models, but to ensure they’re explainable, monitored, and integrated into decision systems.And increasingly, we’re seeing the need for platform thinking: building reusable data products, not just bespoke dashboards.AI-native tools are already reshaping what’s possible, but I believe the core value still lies in clarity, trust, and alignment between data and business goals.💡No one structure fits all — but understanding your current stage helps you build the right team, at the right time, to deliver real impact.🫵And hey — if you made it to the end: I’m currently hiring. We’re building something exciting, and I’m looking for data stewards, data engineers, and data scientists to join our team.DM me if you’re curious.hashtag#CDO hashtag#BankingInnovation hashtag#DataGovernance hashtag#AnalyticsEngineering hashtag#DataStrategy hashtag#DataLeadership hashtag#AIinBanking

✍️The structure of high-performing data teams is evolving — and context is everything.🧠As a CDO in the banking sector, I see firsthand how the right data team composition depends heavily on company size, regulatory environment, and data maturity.The recent benchmark shared on the balance between Insights (46%), Data Engineering (43%), and Machine Learning (11%) resonates — but I’d add a few reflections based on experience leading data transformations in both traditional and digital banking environments:1. In early maturity stages, especially in highly regulated industries like banking, data engineering and governance are foundational. Without robust pipelines, metadata management, lineage tracking, and data quality controls, insights are unreliable — and regulatory risk increases.I often tell teams: “We earn the right to do ML by getting the basics right first.”2. As maturity builds, we focus on embedding analytics across the business — especially in risk, fraud, customer experience, and credit. This is where a strong layer of product analysts and embedded BI starts driving tangible business impact.3. At scale, roles like data product managers, governance leads, and ML engineers become critical — not just to deliver models, but to ensure they’re explainable, monitored, and integrated into decision systems.And increasingly, we’re seeing the need for platform thinking: building reusable data products, not just bespoke dashboards.AI-native tools are already reshaping what’s possible, but I believe the core value still lies in clarity, trust, and alignment between data and business goals.💡No one structure fits all — but understanding your current stage helps you build the right team, at the right time, to deliver real impact.🫵And hey — if you made it to the end: I’m currently hiring. We’re building something exciting, and I’m looking for data stewards, data engineers, and data scientists to join our team.DM me if you’re curious.hashtag#CDO hashtag#BankingInnovation hashtag#DataGovernance hashtag#AnalyticsEngineering hashtag#DataStrategy hashtag#DataLeadership hashtag#AIinBanking

✍️The structure of high-performing data teams is evolving — and context is everything.🧠As a CDO in the banking sector, I see firsthand how the right data team composition depends heavily on company size, regulatory environment, and data maturity.The recent benchmark shared on the balance between Insights (46%), Data Engineering (43%), and Machine Learning (11%) resonates — but I’d add a few reflections based on experience leading data transformations in both traditional and digital banking environments:1. In early maturity stages, especially in highly regulated industries like banking, data engineering and governance are foundational. Without robust pipelines, metadata management, lineage tracking, and data quality controls, insights are unreliable — and regulatory risk increases.I often tell teams: “We earn the right to do ML by getting the basics right first.”2. As maturity builds, we focus on embedding analytics across the business — especially in risk, fraud, customer experience, and credit. This is where a strong layer of product analysts and embedded BI starts driving tangible business impact.3. At scale, roles like data product managers, governance leads, and ML engineers become critical — not just to deliver models, but to ensure they’re explainable, monitored, and integrated into decision systems.And increasingly, we’re seeing the need for platform thinking: building reusable data products, not just bespoke dashboards.AI-native tools are already reshaping what’s possible, but I believe the core value still lies in clarity, trust, and alignment between data and business goals.💡No one structure fits all — but understanding your current stage helps you build the right team, at the right time, to deliver real impact.🫵And hey — if you made it to the end: I’m currently hiring. We’re building something exciting, and I’m looking for data stewards, data engineers, and data scientists to join our team.DM me if you’re curious.hashtag#CDO hashtag#BankingInnovation hashtag#DataGovernance hashtag#AnalyticsEngineering hashtag#DataStrategy hashtag#DataLeadership hashtag#AIinBanking

✍️The structure of high-performing data teams is evolving — and context is everything.🧠As a CDO in the banking sector, I see firsthand how the right data team composition depends heavily on company size, regulatory environment, and data maturity.The recent benchmark shared on the balance between Insights (46%), Data Engineering (43%), and Machine Learning (11%) resonates — but I’d add a few reflections based on experience leading data transformations in both traditional and digital banking environments:1. In early maturity stages, especially in highly regulated industries like banking, data engineering and governance are foundational. Without robust pipelines, metadata management, lineage tracking, and data quality controls, insights are unreliable — and regulatory risk increases.I often tell teams: “We earn the right to do ML by getting the basics right first.”2. As maturity builds, we focus on embedding analytics across the business — especially in risk, fraud, customer experience, and credit. This is where a strong layer of product analysts and embedded BI starts driving tangible business impact.3. At scale, roles like data product managers, governance leads, and ML engineers become critical — not just to deliver models, but to ensure they’re explainable, monitored, and integrated into decision systems.And increasingly, we’re seeing the need for platform thinking: building reusable data products, not just bespoke dashboards.AI-native tools are already reshaping what’s possible, but I believe the core value still lies in clarity, trust, and alignment between data and business goals.💡No one structure fits all — but understanding your current stage helps you build the right team, at the right time, to deliver real impact.🫵And hey — if you made it to the end: I’m currently hiring. We’re building something exciting, and I’m looking for data stewards, data engineers, and data scientists to join our team.DM me if you’re curious.hashtag#CDO hashtag#BankingInnovation hashtag#DataGovernance hashtag#AnalyticsEngineering hashtag#DataStrategy hashtag#DataLeadership hashtag#AIinBanking

✍️The structure of high-performing data teams is evolving — and context is everything.🧠As a CDO in the banking sector, I see firsthand how the right data team composition depends heavily on company size, regulatory environment, and data maturity.The recent benchmark shared on the balance between Insights (46%), Data Engineering (43%), and Machine Learning (11%) resonates — but I’d add a few reflections based on experience leading data transformations in both traditional and digital banking environments:1. In early maturity stages, especially in highly regulated industries like banking, data engineering and governance are foundational. Without robust pipelines, metadata management, lineage tracking, and data quality controls, insights are unreliable — and regulatory risk increases.I often tell teams: “We earn the right to do ML by getting the basics right first.”2. As maturity builds, we focus on embedding analytics across the business — especially in risk, fraud, customer experience, and credit. This is where a strong layer of product analysts and embedded BI starts driving tangible business impact.3. At scale, roles like data product managers, governance leads, and ML engineers become critical — not just to deliver models, but to ensure they’re explainable, monitored, and integrated into decision systems.And increasingly, we’re seeing the need for platform thinking: building reusable data products, not just bespoke dashboards.AI-native tools are already reshaping what’s possible, but I believe the core value still lies in clarity, trust, and alignment between data and business goals.💡No one structure fits all — but understanding your current stage helps you build the right team, at the right time, to deliver real impact.🫵And hey — if you made it to the end: I’m currently hiring. We’re building something exciting, and I’m looking for data stewards, data engineers, and data scientists to join our team.DM me if you’re curious.hashtag#CDO hashtag#BankingInnovation hashtag#DataGovernance hashtag#AnalyticsEngineering hashtag#DataStrategy hashtag#DataLeadership hashtag#AIinBanking

✍️The structure of high-performing data teams is evolving — and context is everything.🧠As a CDO in the banking sector, I see firsthand how the right data team composition depends heavily on company size, regulatory environment, and data maturity.The recent benchmark shared on the balance between Insights (46%), Data Engineering (43%), and Machine Learning (11%) resonates — but I’d add a few reflections based on experience leading data transformations in both traditional and digital banking environments:1. In early maturity stages, especially in highly regulated industries like banking, data engineering and governance are foundational. Without robust pipelines, metadata management, lineage tracking, and data quality controls, insights are unreliable — and regulatory risk increases.I often tell teams: “We earn the right to do ML by getting the basics right first.”2. As maturity builds, we focus on embedding analytics across the business — especially in risk, fraud, customer experience, and credit. This is where a strong layer of product analysts and embedded BI starts driving tangible business impact.3. At scale, roles like data product managers, governance leads, and ML engineers become critical — not just to deliver models, but to ensure they’re explainable, monitored, and integrated into decision systems.And increasingly, we’re seeing the need for platform thinking: building reusable data products, not just bespoke dashboards.AI-native tools are already reshaping what’s possible, but I believe the core value still lies in clarity, trust, and alignment between data and business goals.💡No one structure fits all — but understanding your current stage helps you build the right team, at the right time, to deliver real impact.🫵And hey — if you made it to the end: I’m currently hiring. We’re building something exciting, and I’m looking for data stewards, data engineers, and data scientists to join our team.DM me if you’re curious.hashtag#CDO hashtag#BankingInnovation hashtag#DataGovernance hashtag#AnalyticsEngineering hashtag#DataStrategy hashtag#DataLeadership hashtag#AIinBanking

✍️The structure of high-performing data teams is evolving — and context is everything.🧠As a CDO in the banking sector, I see firsthand how the right data team composition depends heavily on company size, regulatory environment, and data maturity.The recent benchmark shared on the balance between Insights (46%), Data Engineering (43%), and Machine Learning (11%) resonates — but I’d add a few reflections based on experience leading data transformations in both traditional and digital banking environments:1. In early maturity stages, especially in highly regulated industries like banking, data engineering and governance are foundational. Without robust pipelines, metadata management, lineage tracking, and data quality controls, insights are unreliable — and regulatory risk increases.I often tell teams: “We earn the right to do ML by getting the basics right first.”2. As maturity builds, we focus on embedding analytics across the business — especially in risk, fraud, customer experience, and credit. This is where a strong layer of product analysts and embedded BI starts driving tangible business impact.3. At scale, roles like data product managers, governance leads, and ML engineers become critical — not just to deliver models, but to ensure they’re explainable, monitored, and integrated into decision systems.And increasingly, we’re seeing the need for platform thinking: building reusable data products, not just bespoke dashboards.AI-native tools are already reshaping what’s possible, but I believe the core value still lies in clarity, trust, and alignment between data and business goals.💡No one structure fits all — but understanding your current stage helps you build the right team, at the right time, to deliver real impact.🫵And hey — if you made it to the end: I’m currently hiring. We’re building something exciting, and I’m looking for data stewards, data engineers, and data scientists to join our team.DM me if you’re curious.hashtag#CDO hashtag#BankingInnovation hashtag#DataGovernance hashtag#AnalyticsEngineering hashtag#DataStrategy hashtag#DataLeadership hashtag#AIinBanking

✍️The structure of high-performing data teams is evolving — and context is everything.🧠As a CDO in the banking sector, I see firsthand how the right data team composition depends heavily on company size, regulatory environment, and data maturity.The recent benchmark shared on the balance between Insights (46%), Data Engineering (43%), and Machine Learning (11%) resonates — but I’d add a few reflections based on experience leading data transformations in both traditional and digital banking environments:1. In early maturity stages, especially in highly regulated industries like banking, data engineering and governance are foundational. Without robust pipelines, metadata management, lineage tracking, and data quality controls, insights are unreliable — and regulatory risk increases.I often tell teams: “We earn the right to do ML by getting the basics right first.”2. As maturity builds, we focus on embedding analytics across the business — especially in risk, fraud, customer experience, and credit. This is where a strong layer of product analysts and embedded BI starts driving tangible business impact.3. At scale, roles like data product managers, governance leads, and ML engineers become critical — not just to deliver models, but to ensure they’re explainable, monitored, and integrated into decision systems.And increasingly, we’re seeing the need for platform thinking: building reusable data products, not just bespoke dashboards.AI-native tools are already reshaping what’s possible, but I believe the core value still lies in clarity, trust, and alignment between data and business goals.💡No one structure fits all — but understanding your current stage helps you build the right team, at the right time, to deliver real impact.🫵And hey — if you made it to the end: I’m currently hiring. We’re building something exciting, and I’m looking for data stewards, data engineers, and data scientists to join our team.DM me if you’re curious.hashtag#CDO hashtag#BankingInnovation hashtag#DataGovernance hashtag#AnalyticsEngineering hashtag#DataStrategy hashtag#DataLeadership hashtag#AIinBanking

✍️The structure of high-performing data teams is evolving — and context is everything.🧠As a CDO in the banking sector, I see firsthand how the right data team composition depends heavily on company size, regulatory environment, and data maturity.The recent benchmark shared on the balance between Insights (46%), Data Engineering (43%), and Machine Learning (11%) resonates — but I’d add a few reflections based on experience leading data transformations in both traditional and digital banking environments:1. In early maturity stages, especially in highly regulated industries like banking, data engineering and governance are foundational. Without robust pipelines, metadata management, lineage tracking, and data quality controls, insights are unreliable — and regulatory risk increases.I often tell teams: “We earn the right to do ML by getting the basics right first.”2. As maturity builds, we focus on embedding analytics across the business — especially in risk, fraud, customer experience, and credit. This is where a strong layer of product analysts and embedded BI starts driving tangible business impact.3. At scale, roles like data product managers, governance leads, and ML engineers become critical — not just to deliver models, but to ensure they’re explainable, monitored, and integrated into decision systems.And increasingly, we’re seeing the need for platform thinking: building reusable data products, not just bespoke dashboards.AI-native tools are already reshaping what’s possible, but I believe the core value still lies in clarity, trust, and alignment between data and business goals.💡No one structure fits all — but understanding your current stage helps you build the right team, at the right time, to deliver real impact.🫵And hey — if you made it to the end: I’m currently hiring. We’re building something exciting, and I’m looking for data stewards, data engineers, and data scientists to join our team.DM me if you’re curious.hashtag#CDO hashtag#BankingInnovation hashtag#DataGovernance hashtag#AnalyticsEngineering hashtag#DataStrategy hashtag#DataLeadership hashtag#AIinBanking

✍️The structure of high-performing data teams is evolving — and context is everything.🧠As a CDO in the banking sector, I see firsthand how the right data team composition depends heavily on company size, regulatory environment, and data maturity.The recent benchmark shared on the balance between Insights (46%), Data Engineering (43%), and Machine Learning (11%) resonates — but I’d add a few reflections based on experience leading data transformations in both traditional and digital banking environments:1. In early maturity stages, especially in highly regulated industries like banking, data engineering and governance are foundational. Without robust pipelines, metadata management, lineage tracking, and data quality controls, insights are unreliable — and regulatory risk increases.I often tell teams: “We earn the right to do ML by getting the basics right first.”2. As maturity builds, we focus on embedding analytics across the business — especially in risk, fraud, customer experience, and credit. This is where a strong layer of product analysts and embedded BI starts driving tangible business impact.3. At scale, roles like data product managers, governance leads, and ML engineers become critical — not just to deliver models, but to ensure they’re explainable, monitored, and integrated into decision systems.And increasingly, we’re seeing the need for platform thinking: building reusable data products, not just bespoke dashboards.AI-native tools are already reshaping what’s possible, but I believe the core value still lies in clarity, trust, and alignment between data and business goals.💡No one structure fits all — but understanding your current stage helps you build the right team, at the right time, to deliver real impact.🫵And hey — if you made it to the end: I’m currently hiring. We’re building something exciting, and I’m looking for data stewards, data engineers, and data scientists to join our team.DM me if you’re curious.hashtag#CDO hashtag#BankingInnovation hashtag#DataGovernance hashtag#AnalyticsEngineering hashtag#DataStrategy hashtag#DataLeadership hashtag#AIinBanking

✍️The structure of high-performing data teams is evolving — and context is everything.🧠As a CDO in the banking sector, I see firsthand how the right data team composition depends heavily on company size, regulatory environment, and data maturity.The recent benchmark shared on the balance between Insights (46%), Data Engineering (43%), and Machine Learning (11%) resonates — but I’d add a few reflections based on experience leading data transformations in both traditional and digital banking environments:1. In early maturity stages, especially in highly regulated industries like banking, data engineering and governance are foundational. Without robust pipelines, metadata management, lineage tracking, and data quality controls, insights are unreliable — and regulatory risk increases.I often tell teams: “We earn the right to do ML by getting the basics right first.”2. As maturity builds, we focus on embedding analytics across the business — especially in risk, fraud, customer experience, and credit. This is where a strong layer of product analysts and embedded BI starts driving tangible business impact.3. At scale, roles like data product managers, governance leads, and ML engineers become critical — not just to deliver models, but to ensure they’re explainable, monitored, and integrated into decision systems.And increasingly, we’re seeing the need for platform thinking: building reusable data products, not just bespoke dashboards.AI-native tools are already reshaping what’s possible, but I believe the core value still lies in clarity, trust, and alignment between data and business goals.💡No one structure fits all — but understanding your current stage helps you build the right team, at the right time, to deliver real impact.🫵And hey — if you made it to the end: I’m currently hiring. We’re building something exciting, and I’m looking for data stewards, data engineers, and data scientists to join our team.DM me if you’re curious.hashtag#CDO hashtag#BankingInnovation hashtag#DataGovernance hashtag#AnalyticsEngineering hashtag#DataStrategy hashtag#DataLeadership hashtag#AIinBanking

✍️The structure of high-performing data teams is evolving — and context is everything.🧠As a CDO in the banking sector, I see firsthand how the right data team composition depends heavily on company size, regulatory environment, and data maturity.The recent benchmark shared on the balance between Insights (46%), Data Engineering (43%), and Machine Learning (11%) resonates — but I’d add a few reflections based on experience leading data transformations in both traditional and digital banking environments:1. In early maturity stages, especially in highly regulated industries like banking, data engineering and governance are foundational. Without robust pipelines, metadata management, lineage tracking, and data quality controls, insights are unreliable — and regulatory risk increases.I often tell teams: “We earn the right to do ML by getting the basics right first.”2. As maturity builds, we focus on embedding analytics across the business — especially in risk, fraud, customer experience, and credit. This is where a strong layer of product analysts and embedded BI starts driving tangible business impact.3. At scale, roles like data product managers, governance leads, and ML engineers become critical — not just to deliver models, but to ensure they’re explainable, monitored, and integrated into decision systems.And increasingly, we’re seeing the need for platform thinking: building reusable data products, not just bespoke dashboards.AI-native tools are already reshaping what’s possible, but I believe the core value still lies in clarity, trust, and alignment between data and business goals.💡No one structure fits all — but understanding your current stage helps you build the right team, at the right time, to deliver real impact.🫵And hey — if you made it to the end: I’m currently hiring. We’re building something exciting, and I’m looking for data stewards, data engineers, and data scientists to join our team.DM me if you’re curious.hashtag#CDO hashtag#BankingInnovation hashtag#DataGovernance hashtag#AnalyticsEngineering hashtag#DataStrategy hashtag#DataLeadership hashtag#AIinBanking

✍️The structure of high-performing data teams is evolving — and context is everything.🧠As a CDO in the banking sector, I see firsthand how the right data team composition depends heavily on company size, regulatory environment, and data maturity.The recent benchmark shared on the balance between Insights (46%), Data Engineering (43%), and Machine Learning (11%) resonates — but I’d add a few reflections based on experience leading data transformations in both traditional and digital banking environments:1. In early maturity stages, especially in highly regulated industries like banking, data engineering and governance are foundational. Without robust pipelines, metadata management, lineage tracking, and data quality controls, insights are unreliable — and regulatory risk increases.I often tell teams: “We earn the right to do ML by getting the basics right first.”2. As maturity builds, we focus on embedding analytics across the business — especially in risk, fraud, customer experience, and credit. This is where a strong layer of product analysts and embedded BI starts driving tangible business impact.3. At scale, roles like data product managers, governance leads, and ML engineers become critical — not just to deliver models, but to ensure they’re explainable, monitored, and integrated into decision systems.And increasingly, we’re seeing the need for platform thinking: building reusable data products, not just bespoke dashboards.AI-native tools are already reshaping what’s possible, but I believe the core value still lies in clarity, trust, and alignment between data and business goals.💡No one structure fits all — but understanding your current stage helps you build the right team, at the right time, to deliver real impact.🫵And hey — if you made it to the end: I’m currently hiring. We’re building something exciting, and I’m looking for data stewards, data engineers, and data scientists to join our team.DM me if you’re curious.hashtag#CDO hashtag#BankingInnovation hashtag#DataGovernance hashtag#AnalyticsEngineering hashtag#DataStrategy hashtag#DataLeadership hashtag#AIinBanking

✍️The structure of high-performing data teams is evolving — and context is everything.🧠As a CDO in the banking sector, I see firsthand how the right data team composition depends heavily on company size, regulatory environment, and data maturity.The recent benchmark shared on the balance between Insights (46%), Data Engineering (43%), and Machine Learning (11%) resonates — but I’d add a few reflections based on experience leading data transformations in both traditional and digital banking environments:1. In early maturity stages, especially in highly regulated industries like banking, data engineering and governance are foundational. Without robust pipelines, metadata management, lineage tracking, and data quality controls, insights are unreliable — and regulatory risk increases.I often tell teams: “We earn the right to do ML by getting the basics right first.”2. As maturity builds, we focus on embedding analytics across the business — especially in risk, fraud, customer experience, and credit. This is where a strong layer of product analysts and embedded BI starts driving tangible business impact.3. At scale, roles like data product managers, governance leads, and ML engineers become critical — not just to deliver models, but to ensure they’re explainable, monitored, and integrated into decision systems.And increasingly, we’re seeing the need for platform thinking: building reusable data products, not just bespoke dashboards.AI-native tools are already reshaping what’s possible, but I believe the core value still lies in clarity, trust, and alignment between data and business goals.💡No one structure fits all — but understanding your current stage helps you build the right team, at the right time, to deliver real impact.🫵And hey — if you made it to the end: I’m currently hiring. We’re building something exciting, and I’m looking for data stewards, data engineers, and data scientists to join our team.DM me if you’re curious.hashtag#CDO hashtag#BankingInnovation hashtag#DataGovernance hashtag#AnalyticsEngineering hashtag#DataStrategy hashtag#DataLeadership hashtag#AIinBanking

✍️The structure of high-performing data teams is evolving — and context is everything.🧠As a CDO in the banking sector, I see firsthand how the right data team composition depends heavily on company size, regulatory environment, and data maturity.The recent benchmark shared on the balance between Insights (46%), Data Engineering (43%), and Machine Learning (11%) resonates — but I’d add a few reflections based on experience leading data transformations in both traditional and digital banking environments:1. In early maturity stages, especially in highly regulated industries like banking, data engineering and governance are foundational. Without robust pipelines, metadata management, lineage tracking, and data quality controls, insights are unreliable — and regulatory risk increases.I often tell teams: “We earn the right to do ML by getting the basics right first.”2. As maturity builds, we focus on embedding analytics across the business — especially in risk, fraud, customer experience, and credit. This is where a strong layer of product analysts and embedded BI starts driving tangible business impact.3. At scale, roles like data product managers, governance leads, and ML engineers become critical — not just to deliver models, but to ensure they’re explainable, monitored, and integrated into decision systems.And increasingly, we’re seeing the need for platform thinking: building reusable data products, not just bespoke dashboards.AI-native tools are already reshaping what’s possible, but I believe the core value still lies in clarity, trust, and alignment between data and business goals.💡No one structure fits all — but understanding your current stage helps you build the right team, at the right time, to deliver real impact.🫵And hey — if you made it to the end: I’m currently hiring. We’re building something exciting, and I’m looking for data stewards, data engineers, and data scientists to join our team.DM me if you’re curious.hashtag#CDO hashtag#BankingInnovation hashtag#DataGovernance hashtag#AnalyticsEngineering hashtag#DataStrategy hashtag#DataLeadership hashtag#AIinBanking

✍️The structure of high-performing data teams is evolving — and context is everything.🧠As a CDO in the banking sector, I see firsthand how the right data team composition depends heavily on company size, regulatory environment, and data maturity.The recent benchmark shared on the balance between Insights (46%), Data Engineering (43%), and Machine Learning (11%) resonates — but I’d add a few reflections based on experience leading data transformations in both traditional and digital banking environments:1. In early maturity stages, especially in highly regulated industries like banking, data engineering and governance are foundational. Without robust pipelines, metadata management, lineage tracking, and data quality controls, insights are unreliable — and regulatory risk increases.I often tell teams: “We earn the right to do ML by getting the basics right first.”2. As maturity builds, we focus on embedding analytics across the business — especially in risk, fraud, customer experience, and credit. This is where a strong layer of product analysts and embedded BI starts driving tangible business impact.3. At scale, roles like data product managers, governance leads, and ML engineers become critical — not just to deliver models, but to ensure they’re explainable, monitored, and integrated into decision systems.And increasingly, we’re seeing the need for platform thinking: building reusable data products, not just bespoke dashboards.AI-native tools are already reshaping what’s possible, but I believe the core value still lies in clarity, trust, and alignment between data and business goals.💡No one structure fits all — but understanding your current stage helps you build the right team, at the right time, to deliver real impact.🫵And hey — if you made it to the end: I’m currently hiring. We’re building something exciting, and I’m looking for data stewards, data engineers, and data scientists to join our team.DM me if you’re curious.hashtag#CDO hashtag#BankingInnovation hashtag#DataGovernance hashtag#AnalyticsEngineering hashtag#DataStrategy hashtag#DataLeadership hashtag#AIinBanking

✍️The structure of high-performing data teams is evolving — and context is everything.🧠As a CDO in the banking sector, I see firsthand how the right data team composition depends heavily on company size, regulatory environment, and data maturity.The recent benchmark shared on the balance between Insights (46%), Data Engineering (43%), and Machine Learning (11%) resonates — but I’d add a few reflections based on experience leading data transformations in both traditional and digital banking environments:1. In early maturity stages, especially in highly regulated industries like banking, data engineering and governance are foundational. Without robust pipelines, metadata management, lineage tracking, and data quality controls, insights are unreliable — and regulatory risk increases.I often tell teams: “We earn the right to do ML by getting the basics right first.”2. As maturity builds, we focus on embedding analytics across the business — especially in risk, fraud, customer experience, and credit. This is where a strong layer of product analysts and embedded BI starts driving tangible business impact.3. At scale, roles like data product managers, governance leads, and ML engineers become critical — not just to deliver models, but to ensure they’re explainable, monitored, and integrated into decision systems.And increasingly, we’re seeing the need for platform thinking: building reusable data products, not just bespoke dashboards.AI-native tools are already reshaping what’s possible, but I believe the core value still lies in clarity, trust, and alignment between data and business goals.💡No one structure fits all — but understanding your current stage helps you build the right team, at the right time, to deliver real impact.🫵And hey — if you made it to the end: I’m currently hiring. We’re building something exciting, and I’m looking for data stewards, data engineers, and data scientists to join our team.DM me if you’re curious.hashtag#CDO hashtag#BankingInnovation hashtag#DataGovernance hashtag#AnalyticsEngineering hashtag#DataStrategy hashtag#DataLeadership hashtag#AIinBanking

Post Content:

✍️The structure of high-performing data teams is evolving — and context is everything.🧠As a CDO in the banking sector, I see firsthand how the right data team composition depends heavily on company size, regulatory environment, and data maturity.The recent benchmark shared on the balance between Insights (46%), Data Engineering (43%), and Machine Learning (11%) resonates — but I’d add a few reflections based on experience leading data transformations in both traditional and digital banking environments:1. In early maturity stages, especially in highly regulated industries like banking, data engineering and governance are foundational. Without robust pipelines, metadata management, lineage tracking, and data quality controls, insights are unreliable — and regulatory risk increases.I often tell teams: “We earn the right to do ML by getting the basics right first.”2. As maturity builds, we focus on embedding analytics across the business — especially in risk, fraud, customer experience, and credit. This is where a strong layer of product analysts and embedded BI starts driving tangible business impact.3. At scale, roles like data product managers, governance leads, and ML engineers become critical — not just to deliver models, but to ensure they’re explainable, monitored, and integrated into decision systems.And increasingly, we’re seeing the need for platform thinking: building reusable data products, not just bespoke dashboards.AI-native tools are already reshaping what’s possible, but I believe the core value still lies in clarity, trust, and alignment between data and business goals.💡No one structure fits all — but understanding your current stage helps you build the right team, at the right time, to deliver real impact.🫵And hey — if you made it to the end: I’m currently hiring. We’re building something exciting, and I’m looking for data stewards, data engineers, and data scientists to join our team.DM me if you’re curious.hashtag#CDO hashtag#BankingInnovation hashtag#DataGovernance hashtag#AnalyticsEngineering hashtag#DataStrategy hashtag#DataLeadership hashtag#AIinBanking

✍️The structure of high-performing data teams is evolving — and context is everything.🧠As a CDO in the banking sector, I see firsthand how the right data team composition depends heavily on company size, regulatory environment, and data maturity.The recent benchmark shared on the balance between Insights (46%), Data Engineering (43%), and Machine Learning (11%) resonates — but I’d add a few reflections based on experience leading data transformations in both traditional and digital banking environments:1. In early maturity stages, especially in highly regulated industries like banking, data engineering and governance are foundational. Without robust pipelines, metadata management, lineage tracking, and data quality controls, insights are unreliable — and regulatory risk increases.I often tell teams: “We earn the right to do ML by getting the basics right first.”2. As maturity builds, we focus on embedding analytics across the business — especially in risk, fraud, customer experience, and credit. This is where a strong layer of product analysts and embedded BI starts driving tangible business impact.3. At scale, roles like data product managers, governance leads, and ML engineers become critical — not just to deliver models, but to ensure they’re explainable, monitored, and integrated into decision systems.And increasingly, we’re seeing the need for platform thinking: building reusable data products, not just bespoke dashboards.AI-native tools are already reshaping what’s possible, but I believe the core value still lies in clarity, trust, and alignment between data and business goals.💡No one structure fits all — but understanding your current stage helps you build the right team, at the right time, to deliver real impact.🫵And hey — if you made it to the end: I’m currently hiring. We’re building something exciting, and I’m looking for data stewards, data engineers, and data scientists to join our team.DM me if you’re curious.hashtag#CDO hashtag#BankingInnovation hashtag#DataGovernance hashtag#AnalyticsEngineering hashtag#DataStrategy hashtag#DataLeadership hashtag#AIinBanking

✍️The structure of high-performing data teams is evolving — and context is everything.🧠As a CDO in the banking sector, I see firsthand how the right data team composition depends heavily on company size, regulatory environment, and data maturity.The recent benchmark shared on the balance between Insights (46%), Data Engineering (43%), and Machine Learning (11%) resonates — but I’d add a few reflections based on experience leading data transformations in both traditional and digital banking environments:1. In early maturity stages, especially in highly regulated industries like banking, data engineering and governance are foundational. Without robust pipelines, metadata management, lineage tracking, and data quality controls, insights are unreliable — and regulatory risk increases.I often tell teams: “We earn the right to do ML by getting the basics right first.”2. As maturity builds, we focus on embedding analytics across the business — especially in risk, fraud, customer experience, and credit. This is where a strong layer of product analysts and embedded BI starts driving tangible business impact.3. At scale, roles like data product managers, governance leads, and ML engineers become critical — not just to deliver models, but to ensure they’re explainable, monitored, and integrated into decision systems.And increasingly, we’re seeing the need for platform thinking: building reusable data products, not just bespoke dashboards.AI-native tools are already reshaping what’s possible, but I believe the core value still lies in clarity, trust, and alignment between data and business goals.💡No one structure fits all — but understanding your current stage helps you build the right team, at the right time, to deliver real impact.🫵And hey — if you made it to the end: I’m currently hiring. We’re building something exciting, and I’m looking for data stewards, data engineers, and data scientists to join our team.DM me if you’re curious.hashtag#CDO hashtag#BankingInnovation hashtag#DataGovernance hashtag#AnalyticsEngineering hashtag#DataStrategy hashtag#DataLeadership hashtag#AIinBanking

✍️The structure of high-performing data teams is evolving — and context is everything.🧠As a CDO in the banking sector, I see firsthand how the right data team composition depends heavily on company size, regulatory environment, and data maturity.The recent benchmark shared on the balance between Insights (46%), Data Engineering (43%), and Machine Learning (11%) resonates — but I’d add a few reflections based on experience leading data transformations in both traditional and digital banking environments:1. In early maturity stages, especially in highly regulated industries like banking, data engineering and governance are foundational. Without robust pipelines, metadata management, lineage tracking, and data quality controls, insights are unreliable — and regulatory risk increases.I often tell teams: “We earn the right to do ML by getting the basics right first.”2. As maturity builds, we focus on embedding analytics across the business — especially in risk, fraud, customer experience, and credit. This is where a strong layer of product analysts and embedded BI starts driving tangible business impact.3. At scale, roles like data product managers, governance leads, and ML engineers become critical — not just to deliver models, but to ensure they’re explainable, monitored, and integrated into decision systems.And increasingly, we’re seeing the need for platform thinking: building reusable data products, not just bespoke dashboards.AI-native tools are already reshaping what’s possible, but I believe the core value still lies in clarity, trust, and alignment between data and business goals.💡No one structure fits all — but understanding your current stage helps you build the right team, at the right time, to deliver real impact.🫵And hey — if you made it to the end: I’m currently hiring. We’re building something exciting, and I’m looking for data stewards, data engineers, and data scientists to join our team.DM me if you’re curious.hashtag#CDO hashtag#BankingInnovation hashtag#DataGovernance hashtag#AnalyticsEngineering hashtag#DataStrategy hashtag#DataLeadership hashtag#AIinBanking

✍️The structure of high-performing data teams is evolving — and context is everything.🧠As a CDO in the banking sector, I see firsthand how the right data team composition depends heavily on company size, regulatory environment, and data maturity.The recent benchmark shared on the balance between Insights (46%), Data Engineering (43%), and Machine Learning (11%) resonates — but I’d add a few reflections based on experience leading data transformations in both traditional and digital banking environments:1. In early maturity stages, especially in highly regulated industries like banking, data engineering and governance are foundational. Without robust pipelines, metadata management, lineage tracking, and data quality controls, insights are unreliable — and regulatory risk increases.I often tell teams: “We earn the right to do ML by getting the basics right first.”2. As maturity builds, we focus on embedding analytics across the business — especially in risk, fraud, customer experience, and credit. This is where a strong layer of product analysts and embedded BI starts driving tangible business impact.3. At scale, roles like data product managers, governance leads, and ML engineers become critical — not just to deliver models, but to ensure they’re explainable, monitored, and integrated into decision systems.And increasingly, we’re seeing the need for platform thinking: building reusable data products, not just bespoke dashboards.AI-native tools are already reshaping what’s possible, but I believe the core value still lies in clarity, trust, and alignment between data and business goals.💡No one structure fits all — but understanding your current stage helps you build the right team, at the right time, to deliver real impact.🫵And hey — if you made it to the end: I’m currently hiring. We’re building something exciting, and I’m looking for data stewards, data engineers, and data scientists to join our team.DM me if you’re curious.hashtag#CDO hashtag#BankingInnovation hashtag#DataGovernance hashtag#AnalyticsEngineering hashtag#DataStrategy hashtag#DataLeadership hashtag#AIinBanking
